title: Project overview

author: Simon Krek, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: I would like to welcome you in the name of the Alexis Consortium.
But first, before I start with my presentation, I would like to thank the Austrian Academy for the Hospitality for everything they done in preparing this event, in particular to Tonya Visick.
And also Charlie and Vice president of the Academy for the Welcome.
And well, I hope you will enjoy the event.
Let me stress first that we organize the event.

In the way that we can, we could really interact, which means that we will also give presentations, of course, but each session has a lot of time for questions, and we have a special dedicated session at the end where we will discuss what will be presented in these two days.
So it's really important that we also get feedback from you because it's about.
Institutions entering into a project into an infrastructure which is in the making, so it's really important that it's tailored to your needs.
So my job here at the first presentation or first session is to present the project itself.
So what is it about?
And a bit about the program.
So what will happen today and tomorrow?
And then will.
My presentation will be followed with more.
Concrete stuff, so I will stay on a general level.
And after the well, in fact I will explain it through the slides.
So let's start.
With the first one.
I will go a bit.
In the history back in history because Elexis.
As a project, didn't just came about from nothing.
1st.
I would say on a personal note that the whole thing started back in 2910 years ago.
When we gathered at the first conference on the lexicography, so it was dedicated specially to lexicography, it was in love.
Angela nerve in Belgium, and, well, I can say that it was a general feeling at the conference that.
Something is changing so that lexicography is going into digital world.
But we didn't know exactly how and when and.
We had a lot of questions then.
Oh and after that.
Community was formed based on that, I would say and there is a good.
Mechanism in Europe to do that?
It's called cost.
Action.
And it's basically about meetings.
So what is financed is only the meetings that we can discuss and see what we can do on a certain topic.
So gather people around who are working on certain topics and this one was actually lexicography.
It was called European Network of Lexicography.
We had a kickoff meeting, so you see that it took about four years to get there from 2009 kickoff meeting was in 2013.
And all of this observations from the the cost action.
Are valid also in the context of elexis, so prevalence of user generated dictionary is growing and there is a gap forming.
Between scholarly dictionaries and what general public uses.
For consulting information about language.
And there is a lack of common standards where there is always a lack of common standards, but maybe in particular in the context of lexicography.
And in particular, in two in two so.
Two fields inside lexicography.
One is that.
Dictionary started to be digitized so all dictionary started to be digitized and standard for encoding them was lacking and on the other side, new dictionaries were produced.
Digital born dictionaries as we say and also it would be good if they would have a common standard which where you could start making your dictionary from a certain structure so.
Lack of common research paradigm and the one I think this one is really, really important.
The last One South languages are treated as isolated entities.
So what was happening?
Typically there was, let's say an Institute which was dedicated to describing particular language.
Let's say Slovenian, Croatian, German, Danish and so on and it stayed within the language community within the country within the state.
But in the digital world, that's not enough, so there is.
There was a lack of understanding how we can connect all these digital resources.
So that was the start of European network of lexicography action.
And at the end it was.
I think it was quite successful.
We had 280 members from 30 countries.
We had seven meetings in the four years.
A lot of short time scientific missions.
So this is the acronym SDSM.
We had three training schools and we produced one portal at the end.
The portal European diction Reporter and from this.
Cost action.
This elexis project was actually born.
So it was known already.
Within A at the very end of the cost action that it was approved by the.
European Commission so just a bit of information.
About the project itself.
So it started in the 1st of February last year.
The duration is 4 years.
The finances are here on the slide.
It's coordinated by the order Steven Institute from Ljubljana.
We have a large number of partners for European project 17 from 15 countries, but this is not so unusual for infrastructures where you try to.
Form a community.
And most of the information is available on the website.
Co which are the partners?
So from how many 15 countries right?
These are the countries.
One important aspect that has to be emphasized is that in channel cost action there were lexicographers, but too.
Get everything in motion.
We also needed the other side.

The more computational side, which was then added in the consortium so we have partners with lexicographic data and expertise coming basically from the cost action with computational linguistics, data and expertise.
In standardization, because this part is really important, digital humanities and technology partners.
So all of these are combined.
In the project that.
We are showing now.
The goals are to integrate extent harmonized national and regional efforts in the field of lexicography, both modern and historical.
What does that mean?
It means that what I said before.
Until I would say.
2010 most countries or communities or language communities kind of have seen lexicography as a.
As a national thing or a regional thing, but.
The goal was exactly to overcome that.
So to make it to bring it to somehow to European or EU level.
With the goal of creating an infrastructure that then anybody can use which will enable access to high quality lexical data, meaning that everything that well, these.
Regional national.
Efforts are producing will be available to everybody and to bridge the gap between more advanced and lesser resources.
Scholarly communities working on lexicographic resources, meaning that if something a tool or a service or something like that is was developed.
For a particular language that it can be used also for languages that are less resource, have less money to invest in this particular.
Field lexicography
So what is expected after four years?
Well, obviously to provide access to quality lexicographic data.
And to enable massive integration of knowledge based resources.
And this is what we'll try to explain to you today in the now after my presentation and in session after that.
It's not an easy thing to do and.
What we will show today is the plan.
The idea is that we have how to integrate all dictionaries together in one resource.
So with the three.
Also important goals.
To extend what we do to education to industry and to connect with other infrastructures.
And two of them were mentioned today already.
Clarion and Araya, also doing a bit similar things but not so much for lexicography.
And at the end we should have a new type of lexicography that no longer views languages as isolated entities.
It's a Noble goal, I hope will a will be able to achieve it.
And today will try.
Try to show you how.
We would like to achieve that.
Very important quote for my next slide comes from Adam Kilgarriff who passed away in 2015.
Sadly, because we actually started the whole idea together with him after the conference in love and Lineof.
So he said in the best of all possible worlds.
And lexicographical upgrading will build upon each other in a virtuous circle that knew no bounds.
And this is exactly what we would like to do.
It's you know, back from 2000 for it goes way back.
So what what is the plan?
What is the work plan in Alexis?
We would like to make such a circle or cycle that goes between.
Computational linguistics, natural language processing, maybe even artificial intelligence.
Definitely semantic web.
That uses the data that comes from lexicography, so from lexicographers working on different language dictionaries.
Then goes to something that can be processed or understood by computers.
Which can enhance resources that are used by lexicographers to do their lexicographic business, so that's the basic idea.
And.
The.
The call that we applied the project to was actually an infrastructure call which had certain requirements and basically we have three types of activities in the project.
One is research, then there is something called transnational access and virtual access.
It's the basic thing for infrastructure with because you provide access to something to research.
Of something to researchers.
And the third type of activities are networking activities, creating a community and this is what we are trying to do today and tomorrow.
Creating and community working on digital.
Well or other types of dictionaries.
So as Daniel said already, we organized the event in a way that today we are talking about technology, basically more about technology, and tomorrow we'll talk about.
Community building, so how can we provide some service?
To you.
So the.
222 two parts in red.
Are about what you hear about today.
And transnational access and networking will be the topic of tomorrow.
Now, what does virtual access means mean?
Basically you can see it as something that is online.
It's in virtual world and it's something that you can find on the web, basically services tools.
Educational material and so on.
On this slide, you don't have to read anything there.
The important part is Daleks.
Daleks is on the right.
So what we are building is 3.
Sub infrastructures within their access infrastructure one is called.
Well, this was not really normative LX1LX2 unless through you can.
I mean I couldn't find a better.
Name in that moment, so unfortunately it stayed like this, but it's three separate parts anyway, so.
This is a bit more readable now.
What?
I want to show here is actually two paths one goes.
From bottom up and the other one goes from right to left.
Let's call the first one the path of the dictionary.
And the other one the path of the corpus.
Or unstructured data, let's say.
And well, you just have this image, you know.
Keep it in mind.
And this is the path.
Yeah it is a problem.
Get used to it.
So you have a dictionary.
That's the point here.
Let's say you have a dictionary.
What can you do with it?
First thing.
Here.
It gets retro digitized.
Retro is in parenthesis here.
Because Katrien there doesn't like retro because it's basically really just a digitization right?
But you have something on paper and you digitize it, and that's the part that we actually don't cover.
So OCR is not covered by.
It was covered by other projects.
This is what we don't do, but we do everything else from there.
And this is where the standards and data models begin.
So if you have, let's say, if you have a.
A digitized version of a dictionary from the 17th century.
You need to structure it somehow.
You need to know what the headward is, how if there are some senses, or how it's organized.
And this is the first step.
You are using your own data model for your dictionary.
Let's say that you start either in that way or from your own data model.

So you you have a dictionary that was started in the 80s or even later, and you really just prefer to use your own structure for your dictionary because you invented it and it's perfect for your dictionary.
The problem is that it cannot be.
Basically it cannot be used by other people because they don't understand the structure and so on.
So this is the.
The first step, conversion to common data model.
So that anybody else can also see that this is a hard word in your dictionary or anything else now to be able to process this in with computational tools, computers need to understand that.
So the same thing has to be converted into machine readable format.
Which is well, it can be many things, but will probably use format called on Plex and Inside on TALX the Lemon model.
And when we have this, all these bits and pieces identified in dictionaries, we can start linking them.
On various levels.
Lamata lemma sense to sense in what we traveled away.
So what is available to the computer can be linked.
And then what we get if we link everything together is a matrix dictionary or a dictionary matrix.
Which is now.
The new name of the Matrix Dictionary from November, I think.
An Open Access resource with linked data.
So this is what happens with your dictionary.
What happens with your corpus if you have it so?
Let's say that lexicographers for sometime.
Used corpora to get information about language.
Also in previous times, none, not digital times.
On citation slips.
But let's say that we are now in the corporate age and.
What we can do now?
Is process on.
Lower levels, let's say, and what we want to do.
In Alexis is get to semantic level.
So that if computers can understand.
Your own ideas about senses.
Then this can be put in the house whole process and we can use it for annotating or processing corpora.
Using either some common.
Consider some common concepts or something that you use yourself for your language.
So.
Word senses disintegration based on Babel Net or Wikipedia.
That's the common part, and on top of that.
We can do semantic analytics, multi lingual semantic parsing.
And and this is really important and also well it will be shown later.
When we have that.
We can actually enrich your existing dictionaries, meaning that if there is enough.
Annotation quality in the corpora.
Let's say you can.
You can use the.
Pull model as we call it.
It will be explained later.
So that either.
I don't know examples or anything else that is available there in this big resource can be used for your own resource.
And we can also basically create it from the corpus from scratch, let's say.
And the last part.
Which will be shown after I finish.
Is that we will produce.
Services and tools that will be available for everybody.
When you have that kind of data, well enriched or created from scratch.
Or your own.
It can be then worked on.
Manually using online dictionary writing systems.
Also, crowdsourcing platforms and so on.
This is basically the path of the dictionary and the part of the corpus.
So what's in the middle?
This is the tricky part.
And I don't think we know yet.

What we will end up with, but we said that we will create a universal repository of linked senses, meaning description, collocations, phraseology and so on, and universal lexicographic method structure, a dictionary matrix spanning across languages.
In time.
I will not go deeply into that.
We can we can discuss this.
At the end.
So tomorrow in the last session, what can be done?
What are common concepts?
Common conceptualization's that really can go across languages and across time?
So if we go back to the picture that I showed before.
The part that is.
The on the other side of the picture is actually for lexicographers, so it's dedicated for people who are working on lexicographic resources.
And.
The down part is actually necessary to be able to serve lexicographic community by using this.
Let's say clever computational tools.
So.
But we will see now is after I finish we will have the presentation of this upper part likes to call Lex to see.
And Lex one and three will be presented in the session after the coffee break.
And the last session today Session 3, which is in the other building as you heard.
It will be.
Actually, more demo ING, so we will have tables, boots in the other, building 6 of them where you will be able to ask.
All those all presenters from these two sessions.
Now more concrete questions.
How can I so I have like this dictionary?
How can I use your services or will be able to use your services?
When and so on.
Now we are moving to the other part, so if you remember we have.
The transnational access virtual access.
So now we covered virtual access.

Transnational access will be explained more in detail tomorrow, but it's basically about paying people to go somewhere else and learn something new, so that's the transnational access which is also available to all observers.
In and during the project there will be 30 to 40 grants and the first round is finished, so you will be able to talk with grant winners in the poster session and.
More details about.
Transnational access will be explained tomorrow.
And then we come to the just brief representation of the structure.
So what is the idea of community building in Alexis?
So we have the consortium in the middle obviously, but the important part is the middle, the middle part which cover is also observers.
That's basically the next level of Alexis, so the community, which is.
Basically not financed by the EU Commission, but can use all the tools and services.
And more integrated in what we do in the consortium itself.
And this is what we are trying to present today.
And there is even a wider.
Circle around, which covers other infrastructures which deal with kind of similar things but not the same like Clarin and Araya.
And we want to create also kind of international lines for lexicography, which will be also explained tomorrow.
How what the intention is.
There so today or Tuesday.
It's the Community building day and all these things.
So this is from the grant agreement collection of best practices.
This is what we've already done to some extent.
Workshops seminars, which conferences and international forum.
This is basically the.
Alliance for lexicography.
This will be explained in session 4:00 tomorrow morning.
Unt
Sessions five and six.
After all the presentations, it will be easier to show what is the role of observers in Alexis and this will be done in Session 5.
And also what is the relation between Alexis and other existing infrastructures like planning and ariah?
And a very burning issue of Copyright.
So lexicographic resources are usually quite valuable.
You don't want to lose them or abuse them, and we will try to explain how what the plan is to resources still that they would be still useful for this purpose that is described here.
But Copyright would not be breached.
Under general discussion after that.
So we have to move on, but if there are questions.
About what I just presented.
No, then milush.
